  • Endometrial polyps are mostly asymptomatic and benign, but they can cause abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • They donot effect the ovulation, therefore the menses are regular.
  • Endometrial polyps remain intercavitary, therefore the patients have a small , non tender uterus with no visible cervical or vaginal lesions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with dorsal wrist pain which is stiff with very limited range of motion and can’t work as a mechanic. X- rays reveal Grade IV Kienbock’s disease. What is the plan of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The Lichtman classification system essentially divides Kienbock’s disease into types that can be treated with therapeutic operations such as radial shortening or grafting versus those that need salvage operations such as partial or complete wrist arthrodesis.
  • One of the deciding factors in the type of fusion is the degree of fixed deformity. In the presence of fixed deformity, radial shortening is not an option.
  • The Lichtman classification, based on radiographs, is as follows:

Stage 1 – normal (may have a linear or a compression fracture)

Stage 2 – cirrhosis but no collapse

Stage 3A – collapse of entire lunate without fixed scaphoid rotation

Stage 3B – collapse of entire lunate with fixed scaphoid rotation

Stage 4 – stage III with generalized degenerative changes in the carpus

questions.text: Mizuo phenomenon is seen in
questions.solution:
Oguchi diseaseis a form ofcongenital stationary night blindness (CSNB)characterized by:

  • Mizuo - nakamura phenomenon: Change in the light adapted golden yellow colour of the fundus to the normal fundal colour after prolonged Dark Adaptation
  • Genetic: AR, Mutation in rhodopsin kinase gene
  • Fundus is normal in dark but loses its sheen in day light
  • Delayed dark adaptation time
  • Cause: impaired rods activity (overstimulation of rod cells)

questions.text: 25 year old female came to your OPD with Chief complaints of irregular mensturation and excessive growth of hair on her face. USG reveals multiple small cystic structures and also ovary is increased in size. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition ?
questions.solution:
• The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of PCOS.
  • CYP21 gene is located in short arm of chromosome 6, its mutation can cause PCOD.
  • In PCOS there abnormally high levels of androgens which causes excessive facial hair growth.
  • Insulin resistance is present in most of the cases of PCOS.
  • There are high LH and low FSH levels , which causes increased LH:FSH ratio.
  • On USG :
    • Multiple small follicles around the periphery of
    • ovary are seen Ovary in 2-5 time the normal size

questions.text: A 24-year-old builder underwent an L4–L5 discectomy 12 months ago and he still continues to experience pain in his right leg intermittently. He is otherwise in a healthy condition with nothing significant in major test results. For further investigation a Gadolinium Enhanced MRI was performed which showed enhancement adjacent to the right L5 root. There is no fluid collection. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Schwannoma of the right L5 root.

questions.solution:
• Gadolinium-enhanced MRI scans are helpful post discectomy in differentiating between recurrence of disc herniation, which does not enhance with gadolinium, and perineural fibrosis, which shows enhancement around the root.
  • A schwannoma enhances with gadolinium although the root would be enlarged .
  • Systemically the patient is well and there is no evidence of fluid collection on scanning to suggest an infective process.’

questions.text: A 45-year-old cirrhotic patient presented with severe hematemesis. The management of choice is:
questions.solution:
Control of acute bleeding

Treatment is aimed at resuscitating the patient, controlling the bleeding, and preventing complications .

  1. Two large-bore IV access lines should be inserted immediately. RBCs should be transfused with the goal of maintaining the hematocrit value around 25%. A restrictive strategy of transfusing RBCs only when the Hgb level drops below 7?g/dL is associated with improved survival in patients with Child-Pugh class A and B cirrhosis, as compared with a strategy of transfusing when the Hgb level drops below 9?g/dL.
  2. Saline may be infused IV until packed RBCs are available for transfusion.
  3. In patients with active bleeding, the airway needs to be protected, and endotracheal intubation is advised.
  4. Antibiotics should be administered to all patients to prevent bacteremia and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  5. A combination of endoscopic therapy and pharmacologic therapy of variceal bleeding is superior to pharmacologic treatment alone.
  • Pharmacologic agents should be started as early as possible; Somatostatin, octreotide, vapreotide, or terlipressin are the options for pharmacologic therapy.
  • octreotide has been the agent used most commonly. Terlipressin is the first choice in many other countries because it has been associated with improved survival.
  • Endoscopic therapy is carried out as soon as the patient is hemodynamically stabilized.

questions.text: A 5 year old fair child with blue eyes has intellectual disability. The child’s head is very small as compared to other normal children of his age. While investigating FeCl3 test with urine shows green colour. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
PHENYLKETONURIA

  • It is an autosomal recessive disease which occurs due to deficiency of phenylalaninehydroxylase
  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase converts phenylalanine to other important compounds in the body like tyrosine.
  • C/F :
    • Hypopigementation ( fair skin, blonde hair, blue iris)
    • Hypertonia
    • Mental retardation

Investigations :

  • Ferric chloride test : positive (shows green colour)
  • Guthrie test : positive
  • Plasma HPLC/TMS : elevated phenylalanine and its metabolites

Treatment : Low phenylalanine diet with tyrosine supplementation.

questions.text: The duration of anesthesia decreases when less than the recommended dose of anesthetic is administered. However, excessive amounts will not increase the duration of anesthesia.

choices.text: The first statement is true; the second is false.
The first statement is false; the second is true.

questions.solution:
1. Correct. Both statements are true. Although inadequate doses of anesthetic solution shorten the duration of anesthesia, excessive doses of anesthetic do NOT increase anes-thetic duration.
  2. Both statements are true; inadequate doses of anesthetic solution shorten the duration of anesthesia, but excessive doses do not lengthen it.
  3. The second statement is true; excessive doses of anesthetic solution do not lengthen anesthetic duration.
  4. The first statement is true; inadequate doses of anesthetic solution shorten the duration of anesthesia.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is admitted for hypertensive crisis. In the hospital, blood pressure responds poorly to antihypertensive therapy. The patient complains of palpitations.Her past medical history shows that she developed hypotension during an operation for appendicitis.
Her lab values are as follows: H
ct: 47% (37–48)
WBC: 11 (4.3–10.8)
Plasma glucose: 160 mg/dL (75–115)
Plasma calcium: 11 mg/dL (9–10.5)
The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• A hypertensive crisis in this woman suggests a secondary cause of hypertension
  • In the setting of palpitations,and hyperglycemia, pheochromocytoma should be considered.
  • Pheochromocytomas are derived from the adrenal medulla. They are capable of producing and secreting catecholamines.
  • Unexplained hypotension associated with surgery or trauma may also suggest the disease.
  • Clinical symptoms are the result of catecholamine secretion.
  • For example, the patient’s hyperglycemia is a result of a catecholamine effect of insulin suppression and stimulation of hepatic glucose output.
  • Hypercalcemia has been attributed to ectopic secretion of parathormone-related protein
  • Renal artery stenosis can cause severe hypertension but would not explain the systemic symptoms or laboratory abnormalities in this case.

questions.text: A 29 years old G3P2 moderately obese women went into arrest of descent during labour. The doctor performed a manoeuvre by hyperflexion and abduction of hip joint. Which of the following statement is correct regarding the manoeuvre ?

choices.text: Apply fundal pressure along with it
Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh is the most common nerve to get injured

questions.solution:
The above given case is of Shoulder Dystocia , for which doctor is performing McRObert’s manoeuvre.

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • It is the most effective and first line of management for shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves hyperflexion and abduction of hip joint .
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during McRoberts manoeuvre.
  • Suprapubic pressure is applied simultaneously (not fundal pressure).
  • >90% of the cases will resolve by McRObert’s manoeuvre, if not, than we can do :
    • Woods corkscrew manoeuvre
    • Zavanelli manoeuvre

questions.text: Which of the following is true of calcaneal fractures?

choices.text: They are typically associated with an increased Bohler’s angle.
They are extra-articular in the majority of cases.
The Sanders classification is based upon the number and location of articular fragments on sagittal CT scan.
Bilateral fractures occur in 5–10% of cases

questions.solution:
• Calcaneal fractures occur after an axial load and are bilateral in 5–10% of cases.
  • They are associated with a spinal injury in about 10%.
  • The majority (75%) are intra-articular, and result in a decreased Bohler’s angle (line drawn by connecting the anterior process, highest point on posterior articular surface and superior tuberosity on the lateral radiograph).
  • The Sanders classification is based upon the number and location of articular fragments on the coronal CT scan, with four types, based on the number of fragments of the posterior facet, with displacement of 2 mm considered significant.
  • The wound complication rate is reported to be up to 30%

questions.text: A 37-year-old nurse was admitted to the hospital because of high fever to 102°F. A thorough workup was done in the hospital for over 3 weeks with no significant results. No etiology could be identified and she continues to have temperature spikes which go greater than 102°F too. The least likely diagnosis in this patient can be
questions.solution:
• The term fever of unknown origin (FUO) is applied when significant fever persists without a known cause after an adequate evaluation.
  • Several studies have found the leading causes of FUO to include infections, malignancies, collagen vascular diseases, and granulomatous diseases.
  • As the ability to more rapidly diagnose some of these diseases increases, their likelihood of causing undiagnosed persistent fever lessens. I
  • Infections such as intra abdominal abscesses, tuberculosis, hepatobiliary disease, endocarditis (especially if the patient had previously taken antibiotics), and osteomyelitis may cause FUO.
  • In immunocompromised patients, such as those infected with HIV, a number of opportunistic infections or lymphomas may cause fever and escape early diagnosis
  • Self-limited infections such as influenza should not cause fever that persists for many weeks. Neoplastic diseases such as lymphomas and some solid tumors (e.g., hypernephroma and primary or metastatic disease of the liver) are associated with FUO
  • Factitious fever is most common among young adults employed in health-related positions.
  • A prior psychiatric history or multiple hospitalizations at other institutions may be clues to this condition.
  • Such patients may induce infections by self injection of non sterile material, with resultant multiple abscesses or polymicrobial infections.
  • Alternatively, some patients may manipulate their thermometers.
  • In these cases, a discrepancy between temperature and pulse or between oral temperature and witnessed rectal temperature will be observed

questions.text: A 10 years old girl presented with complaints of severe throat pain. On examination, the patient presents with features depicted below in this image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Types of Acute Tonsillitis
Acute catarrhal/superficial Part of generalized pharyngitis (Viral infections). Tonsils appear red and congested
Acute follicular Infection spread into the crypts with purulent material presenting at the opening of crypts as yellow spots
Acute parenchymatous Tonsils are uniformly enlarged and congested
Acute membranous Exudates coalesce to form membrane on the surface of tonsil

Picture shows pus beads on the surface of left tonsil.So its Acute Follicular Tonsillitis

questions.text: A 35 year old WoodWorker presents to the ER with a lacerated foot after he accidently lost control of his axe. The patient suffers severe hemorrhage and becomes hypotensive. The anesthetic was maintained with nitrous oxide and isoflurane. Isoflurane was discontinued and a small dose of midazolam is given for amnesia. Which of the following is the most appropriate muscle relaxant to administer at this time to avoid excessive hypotension?
questions.solution:
• Pancuronium provides a mild vasoconstrictive effect that is useful when the patient is initially hypotensive and thus prone to worsening hypotension with many other anesthetics.
  • In addition, pancuronium also provides long-lasting muscle relaxation that is important for preventing sudden movement in response to surgical stimulation during long delicate operations.
  • The other agents listed may augment the hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about craniopharyngiomas is true?

choices.text: The primary mode of treatment is radiation therapy
Children with these tumors often develop signs and symptoms of acromegaly
The tumors may cause compression of the optic tracts and visual symptoms

questions.solution:
• Craniopharyngiomas are cystic tumors with areas of calcification and originate in the epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch.
  • These usually benign tumors are found in the sellar and suprasellar region and lead to compression of the pituitary, optic tracts, and third ventricle.
  • As a result they show up on radiographic imaging as an area of sellar erosion with calcification within or above the sella.
  • Craniopharyngiomas are most commonly found in children but may also present in adulthood.
  • In children they can cause growth retardation because of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.
  • Treatment consists of subfrontal or transsphenoidal excision with adjuvant radiotherapy if total removal is not possible.

questions.text: All the following bones contribute to nasal septum, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
NASAL SEPTUM CONSISTS OF 3 PARTS:
Columellar septum Formed of columella containing the medial crura of alar cartilages united together by fibrous tissue and covered on either side by skin.
Membranous septum Consists of double layer of skin only. Lies between the columella & caudal border of septal cartilage (No bony/cartilaginous support)
Septum proper Osteocartilaginous framework, covered with nasal mucous membrane.

Septum proper is made up of

  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer,
  • Large septal (quadrilateral/quadrangular) cartilage wedged between above 2 bones anteriorly.

Other bones which make minor contributions at the periphery are: crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, sphenoid rostrum, crest of palatine bones and crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman with an open tibia/fibula fracture of her left lower extremity underwent uneventful debridement and external fixation. Her initial postoperative course was uneventful. On postoperative day 4, she was noted to have mild swelling of her left ankle and a fever of 38.6°C. Her wounds were without signs of infection and there were no palpable cords. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
• Deep venous thrombosis is an important cause of postoperative morbidity because of the high prevalence and the potentially life-threatening consequences.
  • Clot may propagate from the deep venous system of the lower leg into the femoral and iliac systems.
  • Most pulmonary emboli originate from above the knee.
  • Risk factors include Virchow's triad:
    • vascular stasis (e.g., venous insufficiency, obesity)
    • abnormal vessel walls (e.g., fractures)
    • hypercoagulability (e.g., estrogen therapy, pregnancy, cancer).
  • Diagnosis is sometimes difficult because 50% of patients have no symptoms; the remainder have lower extremity swelling, fever, and pain as well as the classic positive Homan's sign characterized by calf pain with foot dorsiflexion.
  • Fat emboli are not associated with ankle swelling.
  • Iatrogenic lymphatic disruption is rare except with extensive resections of nodal groups.
  • Thrombophlebitis typically presents with erythema, tenderness, and a palpable cord over the affected vein.

questions.text: A 27 year old woman gardener is certain that the landlord's son is in love with her even though he has shown no such interest in her, and is engaged to be married to someone else. She has also started telling co workers about his plans to marry her and gets angry with anyone who tries to convince her about the contrary. The woman can be diagnosed with:
questions.solution:
Erotomania (Delusions of Love) is usually seen in schizophrenia and delusional disorder. Patients with erotomania have a false belief that someone is in love with them.

  • It is also known as de Clerambault syndrome/Fantasy lover syndrome.
  • For example, a rickshaw puller claimed that Katrina Kaif is in love with him though he admitted that he has never met her.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Erotomania is NOT mania. Imagine it's a false word because it's deceiving you, confusing you that it's a mania but it's not. Similarly, it's a condition usually where the poor think that the rich/ celebrity loves them.

Restless leg syndrome / Ekbom syndrome.

  • Sensorimotor disorder, commonly seen in 5-15% of the population.
  • Affects females and after 40 years.
  • 4 salient diagnostic features being :
    • Urge to move limbs, commonly associated with premonitory sensory discomfort
    • Motor restlessness
    • Relief by activity
    • Evening/Night worsening
  • Pathophysiological explanations or mechanisms attributed are:
    • Dysregulation of dopamine transmission
    • Intracellular iron dysregulation. This can be objectively substantiated by decreased CSF ferritin and prohepcidin (Intracellular regulatory protein for iron) levels.

Charles Bonnet Syndrome: ·

  • Visual hallucinations in visually impaired elderly individuals.
  • Characteristic lack of other associated psychiatric symptoms.
  • Simple to complex contents could be part of the visual hallucination.
  • There might or might not be secondary distress.
  • Happens in clear consciousness

Capgras' Syndrome

  • In this, the patient believes that a person, usually closely related to him, has been replaced by an exact double.
  • Eg: A patient starts hitting his wife telling that she is not his wife but she is a nurse and she wants to kill him.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect for neonatal physiological jaundice ?

choices.text: It never occurs in first 24 hours
It can be conjugated or unconjugated
Icterus does not involves palms and soles

questions.solution:
• Physiological jaundice is always Unconjugated
  • If it is conjugated, it is always pathological
PHYSIOLOGICAL JAUNDICE PATHOLOGICAL JAUNDICE
  • It never appears in first 24 hours of life
  • It is always unconjugated ; urine doesn’t stain diaper and no pale stools
  • Palms and soles are never stained yellow
  • Clinical jaundice never persist beyond 3 weeks
  • It may appear in first 24 hours of life
  • It can be conjugated or unconjugated
  • High colored urine and pale stools may be present
  • Palms and soles may be stained yellow
  • It may persist beyond 3 weeks

questions.text: A 6 month old male child was brought to the OPD by his mother, complaining that she can able to hear a sound during inspiration. And specifically it increases on crying & reduces in prone position. Diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Newborn develops intermittent, low-pitched inspiratory stridor within 1st 2 weeks of life ( presents at birth)
  • Severity of stridor increases on crying but reduces in prone position as the epiglottis falls forward in prone position and opens the airway.
  • Stridor usually starts resolving after 9 months, and disappears by 2 years of age.
  • Cry itself as such is normal only but the Stridor increases during inspiratory phase while the child is crying.

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency room with sudden abdominal pain and an expanding, pulsatile abdominal mass on examination. His vital signs are: heart rate, 130 beats/min; blood pressure, 70/20 mm Hg; respiration, 30/min; temperature, 36.0°C. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The triad of acute abdominal pain, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and hypotension is classic for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
  • This patient should be taken to the operating room immediately.
  • Performing a CT scan or aortogram in this situation would only delay definitive operative treatment and is not indicated in this patient.

questions.text:
An asthamatic female developed PPH during a normal vaginal delivery. Her vitals were:
HR- 110/min
BP : 90/60 mmHg
Temperature : 37 degree c
During the management of the patient which of the following should not be given ?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is contraindicated in asthamatics as it causes bronchoconstriction

  • Carboprost is a uterotonic agent used in PPH.
  • It is an alternative drug for PPH due to uterine atony, especially in patients not responding to metehrgin and oxytocin.
  • It is a methyl analogue of PGF 2 alpha.
  • a/k/a Dinoprost or hemabate.
  • It is the most potent drug used for PPH.
  • Dose : 0.25 mg IM.
  • Maximum dose in 24 hours : 2 mg

questions.text: A 20-month-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She tells you that the girl has not spoken her first clear word yet, she also seems not to understand what people say to her, and refuses to play with her 3-year- old brother. The mother also tells you that her daughter seems clumsy and has started to make odd repetitive movements with her hands. Upon further investigation, she had a normal head circumference at birth, at 6 months, and at 12 months, and had seemed to be developing normally. On physical examination, the rate of head growth has slowed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The deceleration of head growth after 6 months of age followed by repetitive, stereotyped behavior (wringing hand movements), impaired communication and poor social interaction is suggestive of Rett’s syndrome

Rett's syndrome is more common in females.

Rett’s disorder (Rett’s syndrome)
  • Almost exclusively seen in Females
  • Normal development till 5 months.
  • Deceleration of head circumference (Microcephaly).
  • Loss of acquired hand skills and speech (Pincer grasp may be absent).

HOW TO REMEMBER: RE-tts= REversal of motor milestones.

AUTISM

  • Impairment in social interaction
    • Reduced eye contact, unusual facial expressions, lack of gestures, poor understanding of others’ feelings.
    • May not value the company of their parents over that of complete strangers
  • Impairment of communication
    • Pronoun reversal
    • May not value the company of their parents over that of complete strangers
  • Restricted/repetitive interests and behaviors – repetitive plays , stereotypes movements, hand wringing & spinning
  • The clinical features of autism must be present by 3 years in order for a diagnosis to be made.

ASPERGER’S SYNDROME

  • Similar to autism however , language dysfunction is not there

Fragile X Syndrome

  • Most common inherited cause of intellectual disability
  • Affects 1 in 2000 females; 1 in 700 females is a carrier
  • Affects between 1 in 4000 and 1 in 6000 live male birth
  • X-linked dominant with low penetrance is the common mode of inheritance
  • IQ lower in males compared to females suffering from intellectual disability
  • Physical anomalies are more characteristic in male population

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female complains of fatigue, constipation, and weight gain. There is no prior history of neck surgery or radiation. On examination, her voice is hoarse and her skin is dry.
Lab tests show Serum TSH is elevated and T4 is low. The most likely cause of these findings is
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with classic features of hypothyroidism
  • Hypothyroidism is almost always caused by autoimmune disease, thyroid damage from surgery, or radiation therapy.
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis usually occurs in women, has a genetic component, and is associated with other autoimmune conditions.
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis may be present with a goiter (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis) or with minimal residual thyroid tissue (atrophic thyroiditis).
  • Primary hypothyroidism can result from surgery or radiation therapy, but there is no such history in this patient.
  • Thyroid cancer does not cause hypothyroidism. It presents with neck mass, hoarse voice, or expanding nodule.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of fever and shortness of breath for the past 1 hour. There is no pleuritic chest pain or associated rigors and no sputum production.Upon further examination, A chest x-ray shows diffuse perihilar infiltrates. The patient started on erythromycin which seems to have worsened his condition. A silver methenamine stain shows cyst-like structures. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Oral antibiotic therapy is not the treatment of choice
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the treatment of choice in the non allergic patient
Tetracycline is more effective than erythromycin

questions.solution:
• The above clinical vignette suggests an infection with p. Carinii pneumonia as Patients with P. carinii pneumonia frequently present with shortness of breath and no sputum production.
  • The interstitial pattern of infiltrates on chest x-ray distinguishes pneumonia from most bacterial infections.
  • Diagnosis is made by review of silver methenamine stains.
  • Trimethoprim-sulfa is the drug of choice for P. carinii pneumonia in the non allergic patient.
  • Oral therapy is recommended for mild to moderate disease.
  • Prednisone has been shown to improve the mortality rate in moderate to severe disease when the PO2 is less than 70 mmHg.
  • Neither tetracycline or erythromycin has any effect on the organism.

questions.text: A 52-year-old, 60-kg woman is admitted to the hospital immediately after being involved in a house fire. She has approximately 50% total body surface area (TBSA) burns that are at least partial-thickness burns. She has not received any intravenous (IV) fluids up to this point. Which of the following is the most appropriate IV fluid and rate of administration that should initially be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The Parkland formula is used to calculate an estimated volume of intravenous (IV) fluids to administer during the first 24 hours after a burn.
  • Thus, 12 liters of IV fluids will need to be given to this patient during the first 24 hours.
  • However, half of the fluid needs to be given in the first 8 hours after the injury; this means that approximately 6 liters will need to be given over an 8-hour period (750 mL/hr).
  • Initial losses are isotonic, and therefore need to be replaced with an isotonic crystalloid such as lactated Ringer's.

questions.text: A girl sustains a needle prick to the left index finger over the distal palmar surface. Initially, she notices little discomfort. However, 3 days after the injury she develops intense pain in the distal phalanx that wakes her up at night. Regarding this situation, which of the following is the most appropriate statement?

choices.text: She has an acute paronychial infection
Drainage is accomplished via an incision over the most tender region
Late sequelae of this type of infection seldom involve the bone
Cultures of the finger will most likely produce a gram-negative rod

questions.solution:
• This patient has a felon, not a paronychial infection.
  • Untreated, the infection may progress to involve the distal phalanx.
  • The most likely organisms are gram-positive cocci.
  • The scar on the volar surface may be tender initially, but no more so than a scar elsewhere on the hand.
  • Incision and drainage is indicated in this situation, with the incision placed directly over the point of maximal tenderness

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the Orthopaedic OPD with sharp, stabbing groin pain associated with turning, twisting, and squatting. He also complains of stiffness in his pelvic area which is most commonly associated with limping. He has a history of mild developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) as a child. Which of the following is the most likely radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
• The patient is likely to be suffering from cam-type femoro-acetabular impingement, often presenting secondary to DDH, Perthes, or slipped upper femoral epiphysis, with a head/ neck junction prominence that may also lead to labral degeneration, cysts and tear.
  • Degenerative changes at the articular surface in mild DDH is rare in a patient of this age, although cysts may be seen at the head/neck junction if there is impingement.

Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) -

  • It’s a condition that characteristically presents with hip pain secondary to mechanical impingement from abnormal hip morphology involving the proximal femur and/or acetabulum
  • Over time, chronic repetitive trauma can lead to hip pain and decreased function.
  • The abnormal bony features include cam deformity of the femoral head-neck junction as well as pincer lesions of the acetabulum.
  • Cam deformity is an abnormal bony prominence at the junction of the femoral head and neck resulting in an aspherical-shaped head, occurring most commonly along the anterosuperior femoral head-neck area.
  • A pincer lesion is an abnormal bony overhang of the anterolateral acetabular rim resulting in over coverage of the femoral head, which can also contribute to impingement and pain.

questions.text: A man sustained a left femur fracture after a steel beam fell on his legs and trapped him underneath for 2 hours. On admission, the patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells for hypotension and had significant blood loss from the femur fracture. On hospital day 2, the patient is noted to have frequent runs of ectopy with widened QRS complexes on the electrocardiogram monitor. His urine is dark red, but microscopic examination of the urine reveals no red blood cells. Which of the following events is most likely responsible for this patient's current findings?

choices.text: Hemolysis secondary to the blood transfusion
Acute tubular necrosis secondary to hypovolemia

questions.solution:
• The most likely cause of the findings in this patient is hyperkalemia associated with rhabdomyolysis.
  • Extensive necrosis of muscle tissue can occur after crush injuries without visible signs of necrosis noted at the level of the skin.
  • Necrosis of muscle cells with subsequent lysis can lead to release of large amounts of K+ from the cytoplasm of these cells, resulting in the widened QRS complex and ectopy seen on the ECG.
  • Hemolysis related to blood transfusion would generally not result in severe hyperkalemia unless it was associated with ABO incompatibility, which occurs within minutes to hours of transfusion.
  • Acute tubular necrosis may occur after periods of hypovolemia and may lead to renal failure and hyperkalemia; however, this generally does not present acutely, as in this patient.
  • Unilateral kidney injuries can occur in the absence of hematuria, although in an otherwise healthy individual this would not affect renal function.

questions.text: A 32 year old multiparous women comes to the emergency at 31 weeks gestation with complaints of painless recurrent bleeding pv. On examination FHS was 135 bpm and fundal height corresponded to gestational age. Which of the following is a risk factor for this condition ?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is of Antepartum haemorrhage.

Painless bleeding PV and fundal height corresponding to gestational age is suggestive of placenta previa

Whereas in abruptio placentae bleeding is painfull and fundal height doesnot corresponds to gestational age.

Risk factors for placenta previa are :

  1. Maternal age > 35 years
  2. Smoking
  3. Multiparity
  4. History of previous cesarean section or any other scar in the uterus (myomectomy or hysterotomy)
  5. Prior curettage

questions.text: A baby is delivered by assisted forceps delivery. After 24 hours the mother noted a swelling over the infant’s head which was not crossing the suture lines. Which of the following is correct regarding this ?

choices.text: It will disappear in 48 to 72 hours
Due to edema in layers of scalp

questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cephalhematoma

CEPHALHEMATOMA :

  • It is due to subperiosteal hemorrhage involving cranial bones.
  • It is not present at birth and it presents as swelling over the head of an infant after 24-48 hours of delivery.
  • It is limited to surface of 1 cranial bone and doesnot cross the suture line.
  • It takes 5-7 weeks to disappear.
  • It predisposes to neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: Band shaped keratopathy is an age-related deposition of calcium salts in ?
questions.solution:
Band Shaped Keratopathy

It is an age-related deposition of calcium salts in the Bowman layer, epithelial basement membrane and anterior stroma.

  • Calcium phosphate/ Calcium hydroxyapatite
  • Deposition in Bowman’s membrane

Band Shaped Keratopathy causes are:

  • chronic anterior uveitis (especially in children with JIA Juvenile idiopathic arthritis also called JRA Juvenile Rheumatoid arthritis)
  • Glaucoma
  • pthisis bulbi
  • silicone oil in anterior chamber
  • chronic corneal edema
  • severe chronic keratitis
  • conditions a/w hyperkalemia such as Hyperparathyroidism, end stage renal failure, hypophospahatasia, Sarcoidosis, Pagets disease, multiple myeloma, Vit D toxicity
  • Hereditary causes inclide familial cases and ichthyosis
  • Age related - affecting otherwise healthy individuals

Treatment:

  • EDTA (1.5-3%) chelation
  • LamellarKeratoplasty
  • PTK -
  • Excimer laser keratectomy
  • Diamond burr

Peripheral interpalpebral calcification with clear cornea separating the sharp peripheral margins of the band from the limbus

Gradual central spread to form a band-like chalky plaque containing transparent small holes

questions.text: Wood lamp’s Examination is a diagnostic Test wherein the skin or the hair is examined under exposure to the Black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Identify the incorrect statement.

choices.text: Made up of Nickel Oxide and silica with Ultraviolet light with a wavelength of 360 nm
Corynebacterium minutissimum shows Golden yellow fluorescence
Wood's lamp enhances epidermal pigmentation but not dermal pigmentation
Mycobacterium leprae displays Blue white colour

questions.solution:
Erythrasma (Corynebacterium minutissimum) displays a Coral red colour and Tinea Versicolour shows Golden yellow fluorescence

The direct examination of the lesions of Tinea versicolor under wood’s lamp show pale yellow fluorescence.

The different infections and conditions showing different colors are:

Disease Color On Wood’s Lamp (360nm UV light used)
1 Erythrasma (Corynebacterium minutissimum) Coral red color
2 Tinea versicolor Golden yellow
3 Tinea capitis (Microsporum canis or M. audouini) Yellow fluorescence.
4 Trichophyton schoenleinii Pale green
5 Microsporum audouinii or M. canis Yellow fluorescence
6 Pseudomonas aeruginosa Pale blue/ Aquagreen
7 Tuberous sclerosis Ash-leaf-shaped spot
8 Porphyria cutanea tarda Pink to pink-orange
9 Leprosy Blue white
10 Hypopigmentation Pale white
11 Hyperpigmentation Purple brown
12 Depigmentation – Vitiligo Totally white
13 Albinism Bright white
14 Pigmented lesions of the epidermis such as freckles are accentuated under a Wood’s light
15 Lesions dermal pigment such as postinflammatory hyperpigmentation fades under a Wood’s light.

questions.text: A non-cyanotic 3 day old child has a systolic murmur along the left sternal border; the examination is otherwise normal. Chest x-ray and ECG are normal. These findings are most closely associated with which of the following congenital cardiac anomalies?
questions.solution:
• Ventricular septal defect accounts for 20–30% of all congenital cardiac anomalies.
  • It may lead to cardiac failure and pulmonary hypertension if the defect is larger than 1 cm; or it may be asymptomatic if the defect is small.
  • Surgery is not indicated for the asymptomatic patient with a small defect since a substantial number of these anomalies close spontaneously during the first few years of life.
  • Operation is indicated in infants with congestive heart failure or rising pulmonary vascular resistance (owing to the left-to- right shunt).
  • When symptoms are mild and can be controlled medically, operation is usually delayed until age 4–6 years.
  • Operative mortality ranges from less than 5% to more than 20% depending on the degree of pulmonary vascular resistance.

questions.text: A female with 39 weeks of gestation was delivered at home by normal vaginal delivery 48 hours ago. She came to emergency with complete perineal tear which happened during delivery . when is the ideal time to repair this ?
questions.solution:
Management of Perineal tear

  • 1st and 2nd degree perineal tear : Repaired just like episiotomy in labour room after delivery.
  • 3rd and 4th degree perineal tear (complete) : It has to be repaired within 24 hours of delivery, because after that the torn ends of sphincter become avascular, then reapir has to be done after 3-6 months.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male complains of hip and back pain. He has also developed headaches, hearing loss, and tinnitus. On physical exam the skull appears enlarged, with prominent superficial veins. There is marked kyphosis, and the bones of the leg appear deformed. A skull x-ray shows sharply demarcated lucencies in the frontal, parietal, and occipital bones. X-rays of the hip show thickening of the pelvic brim. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• This patient has widespread Paget’s disease of bone.
  • Excessive resorption of bone is followed by replacement of normal marrow with dense, trabecular, disorganized bone.
  • Hearing loss and tinnitus are due to direct involvement of the ossicles of the inner ear.
  • Plasma alkaline phosphatase levels represent increased bone turnover.
  • Neither myeloma or metastatic bone disease would result in bony deformity such as skull enlargement.
  • Alkaline phosphatase is a marker of bone formation and does not rise in pure lytic lesions such as multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman complains of episodes of diarrhoea and rectal bleeding. Her father died of colorectal cancer at the age of 41. On further examination, a double contrast barium enema was performed which showed more than one hundred small polyps. They measured approximately 5mm in size and they were spread out throughout the colon. An upper GI endoscopy demonstrates multiple polypoid lesions in the stomach and the duodenum. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the APC gene (chromosome 5q21).
  • It results in the development of hundreds of polyps within the colon and carries a 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer; these patients are there-fore offered prophylactic proctocolectomy with an ileorectal pouch at a young age.
  • Fifty per cent of these patients also develop gastric and duodenal polyps, and therefore require regular endoscopic screening.
  • Gardner's is closely related to FAP, as it is also a consequence of an APC gene mutation, but has additional extraintestinal manifestations;it is a syndrome of colonic polyps, epidermoid cysts and osteomas.
  • Similarly, CHRPE is another variant of FAP; CHRPE may be detected on indirect ophthalmoscopy in up to 75% of those with adenomatous polyposis coli.

Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer is the most common cause of hereditary colon cancer accounting for 3% of all colonic carcinoma.

The genes responsible are various but all function in DNA repair.

The MEN syndromes may have gastrointestinal manifestations, including neuroendocrine tumours of the duodenum and pancreas and megacolon (MEN 2B most commonly, but also 2A) secondary to motility dysfunction. However, adenocarcinoma is not a feature.

Peutz Jeghers syndrome

  • Autosomal dominant condition due to mutation in STK11 gene
  • The polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are generally considered to be hamartomas and are not thought to be at significant risk for malignant degeneration
  • It is characterised by polyposis of the small intestine and to a lesser extent polyposis of the colon and rectum
  • Hamartomatous polyps (usually <100) throughout the GIT, most common in jejunum
  • Associated with Hypomelanotic macules in the perioral region, buccal mucosa.
  • Mucocutaneous pigmentation usually occurs during infancy and most commonly noted in the perioral and buccal region.
  • Pigment spots usually appear in the first few years of life, reach a maximum level in early adolescence and can fade in adulthood. However, pigmentation on the buccal mucosa remains throughout life.
  • The pigmented macules of PJS have no malignant potential.
  • Screening consists of a baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: Steroids can be given for management of all the folllowing ophthalmic condition, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Dendritic ulcer is absolute contraindication for the use of steroids

STEROID IN OPHTHALMOLOGY

  • Contraindication : FUNGAL ULCER
  • DOC in all type of uveitis
  • Systemic steroids have more propensity to cause cataract
  • Topical steroids have more propensity to cause steroid induced rise of IOP
  • ULCER (epithelial defect): Avoid
  • Endothelitis, interstitial KERATITIS: Can provide relief
  • Neurotrophic ULCER: Contraindicated , can aggrevate the conditon
  • Herpetic Dendritic Ulcer – Contraindication
  • Dexamethasone and Prednisolone acetate has higher propensity of causing rise in IOP than Loteprednol and Fluromethalone

questions.text: A 65 year old man is brought to the ER in a Post-ictal state. He gives a history of pulsatile left sided tinnitus for the past 4 weeks. He also has a history of a left craniotomy for the resection of Meningioma 6 months ago. The chances of him developing a dural arteriovenous fistula may be present. Which one of the following investigations would be the most appropriate to confirm this?
questions.solution:
• Conventional MR Angiography and Venography may be completely normal in the setting of dural arteriovenous fistula.
  • Dynamic MR subtraction angiography may be helpful but Intra arterial angiography remains the gold standard

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diabetes, on an oral hypoglycemic, presents to the ER with a right shoulder injury. His heart rate is irregular and the following ECG was obtained. The best immediate therapy would be?
questions.solution:
This ECG shows Mobitz type I second-degree AV block, also known as Wenckebach phenomenon, characterized by progressive PR interval prolongation prior to block of an atrial impulse.

This rhythm generally does not require therapy. ?-?

It may be seen in normal individuals; other causes include inferior MI and drug intoxications such as from digoxin, beta blockers, or calcium channel blockers.

Even in the post-MI setting, it is usually stable, although it has the potential to progress to higher-degree AV block with consequent need for pacemaker.

questions.text: 28 year old primigravida with 32 weeks of gestation came to OPD with chief complaint of painless vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination you see clear fluid coming out of the external os. Her vitals are stable. What will you do next ?

choices.text: Start induction of labour by Oxytoxin 20 IU in 500 ml N.S

questions.solution:
• The above given scenario is suggestive of PROM.
  • In this case we will give her dexamethasone for 48 hours for lung maturation of baby and after that termination of pregnancy has to be done.

questions.text: Following vessels can be ligated in case of intractable Epistaxis, except:
questions.solution:
Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point thus the hierarchy of ligation is:

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Internal maxillary artery
  • External carotid artery
  • Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. He is alert and hemodynamically stable with a right femur fracture. He is transferred to the OT to perform an emergency open reduction procedure for the same. Anesthesiologist induces a rapid sequence anesthesia with sodium thiopental, fentanyl, and succinylcholine. After 30 minutes the ventilation pressures begin to rise while the blood pressure begins to fall. Auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right. A right thoracostomy tube is placed, relieving a tension pneumothorax.
Which agent most likely contributed to the pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
• Nitrous oxide (N20) diffuses into air cavities faster than nitrogen can diffuse out. Therefore, expansion of such potential spaces will continue until the concentration of N20 in the cavity approaches the inspired N20 concentration.
  • Other volatile anesthetic agents such as isoflurane and the other agents mentioned are not associated with expansion of air cavities

questions.text: A 29 year old man was recovering from acute necrotizing pancreatitis, which required operative debridement. On postoperative day 8, he had a large, melenic stool. Blood studies showed a drop in hematocrit from 32% to 26%. A nasogastric tube was placed, which returned minimal “coffee ground” residue (guaiac-positive) with a pH of 4.5. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: Gastrointestinal protection should not routinely be instituted because of the side effects of mucosal-protective drugs
Emergent exploratory laparotomy is indicated to quickly identify the source of bleeding
Gastric ulcers are most likely present, necessitatin immediate treatment for Helicobacter pylori
Proton pump inhibition is an effective method for preventing this condition

questions.solution:
• Mucosal inflammation and hemorrhage occurs frequently in severely ill and septic patients.
  • Diffuse gastritis, duodenitis, and shallow ulcerations are often seen with endoscopy.
  • If the ulceration involves large blood vessels, however, significant bleeding may occur.
  • This is most likely caused by a breakdown of the protective mucosal barrier, rendering the intestinal lining susceptible to the corrosive acidic environment.
  • Effective preventative measures include inhibiting acid production (e.g., histamine receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors) or augmenting the mucosal barrier (e.g., misoprostol, sucralfate [Carafate], antacids) because these agents have few side effects.
  • Emergent laparotomy is not indicated unless medical management fails and the source of bleeding cannot be stopped by any other means (e.g., endoscopy, angiography).
  • Although Helicobacter pylori is a known cause of gastrointestinal ulcer disease and bleeding, it has little influence on stress gastritis or duodenitis
