questions.text: 42 years old female came to your OPD with a chief complaint of post coital bleeding. Examination revealed cervical lesion of 5 cm extending to upper part of vagina without parametrial involvement. What is the stage of the disease ?
questions.solution:
STAGING OF CARCINOMA CERVIX

I → Limited to Cervix

IA → Microscopic Cancer

  • A1 → < 3 mm depth
  • A2 → 3-5 mm depth

IB → Clinical/ macroscopic

  • B1 → < 2 cm
  • B2 → 2 – 4 cm
  • B3 → ≥ 4 cm

IIA→ Upper Vagina Involved without parametrial involvement

  • II A1→ < 4 cm
  • II A2→ ≥ 4 cm

IIB → Parametrial involvement but not upto pelvic wall

IIIA → Lower 1/3rd vaginal involvement

IIIB → Parametrial involvement till the pelvic side wall [Hydronephrosis +](MC Stage of Ca cervix presentation in India → STAGE III B)

III → involvement of pelvic/para aortic lymph nodes

  • C1 → Pelvic lymphnodes involved Imaging
  • C2→ Para Aortic lymphnodes involved

IVA → Bladder & Bowel Involvement

IVB → Distant Metastasis

questions.text: Patient came to OPD with a chief complaint of amenorrhea of 8 weeks associated with pain and spotting p.v. Her UPT was positive , HCG = 3500 IU On Trans vaginal USG there was empty sac. Serial Beta HCG levels were done which showed decreasing trend. Which of the following is correct ?
questions.solution:
• Empty sac at 7 weeks and decreasing trend of HCG levels are suggestive of Missed abortion.
  • In Normal pregnancy, gestational sac is seen on USG around 5 weeks and there is doubling of HCG levels every 36-48 hours.
  • In Ectopic pregnancy, the HCG levels shows slowly increasing trend.
  • In Molar pregnancy, there is increasing trend of HCG levels .

questions.text: 52 years old female came to gynae OPD with a complaint of itching on vagina and also complains of dyspareunia. On examination the vagina was dry. Diagnosis of atrophic vaginitis was made. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this ?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis is topical estrogen vaginal cream.
  • Systemic estrogen therapy is consisdered to prevent recurrence.
  • Topical application of estrogen vaginal cream for weeks will provide relief.

questions.text: 34 year old female married since 5 years had primary infertility, but now she has conceived. She came to emergency with abdominal pain , on USG you found ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Her BP was 106/80, Pulse was 104/min. What will be the management ?
questions.solution:
• Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is an indication for surgical management.
  • As the patient has stable vitals we will prefer Laparoscopy over laparotomy.
  • Salpingostomy is done in cases of unruptured pregnancy, while we do salpingectomy in cases of ruptured ectopic.
  • So, here we will do laparoscopic unilateral salpingectomy for management, which will also preserve the fertility of the female.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the furuncle of ear, Except ?

choices.text: Localised to outer 2/3rd cartilaginous part of EAC
Recurrent furunculosis should be investigated for diabetes mellitus.
Staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle

questions.solution:
A furuncle is a staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle.

  • As the hairs are confined only to the outer 1/3rd cartilaginous part of the meatus, furuncle is seen only in this part of meatus.
  • Symptoms are severe compared to signs as the skin over the EAC is tightly adherent.
  • Signs:
  1. Tragal sign is positive
  2. Obliteration of retroauricular groove
  • Treated by I&D or 10% ichthamol glycerine wicks and antibiotics
  • In case of recurrent furunculosis, diabetes should be ruled out.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoes anesthetic induction for an anterior cruciate ligament repair. She is induced with propofol, lidocaine, and fentanyl. Succinylcholine is administered. The endotracheal tube (ETT) is placed with direct laryngoscopy to 20 cm at the teeth and the oxygen saturation is maintained at 100%. What is the most reliable indication of ETT placement in the trachea?

choices.text: Absence of sound over the epigastrium with ventilation (E) SaO2 of 100% immediately after intubation

questions.solution: Esophageal intubation is only a disaster if unrecognized. Ideally, the endotracheal tube (ETT) is placed through the vocal cords under direct vision. Bilateral breath sounds and ETT condensation can sometimes occur with esophageal intubation. Persistent ETCO2 tracings with ventilation confirms tube placement in the trachea. Tracheal breath sounds can radiate to the epigastrium. One-sided breath sounds represent mainstem intubation, usually right-sided. With optimal pre-oxygenation a healthy individual can take over 5 minutes to desaturate.

questions.text:
A 3 year old child is brought to the ER with breathlessness on exertion. A chest radiograph reveals interstitial change at the lung bases suggestive of Interstitial Lung disease. But the clinical symptoms appear to be more severe than the apparent radiological changes and therefore a confirmed diagnosis is yet to be made.
Which of the following would be the next appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
• HRCT should be ideally performed in order to determine the extent and distribution of the disease.
  • Breathing can be controlled under anesthesia to ensure adequate inspiration

HRCT is particularly useful in the assessment of diffuse lung conditions involving the interstitium such as:

  • interstitial lung disease
  • cystic lung disease
  • small airways disease
  • pulmonary micronodules
  • bronchiectasis

questions.text:
A 24 year old asthmatic man is coming to the OPD with a fever, cough and shortness of breath. A course of Antibiotics has not improved the symptoms. On further investigations, a positive skin test for Aspergillus fumigatus along with an elevated serum IgE is found. The patient is immunocompetent with no previous history of Sarcoidosis or Tuberculosis.
Which of the following are the most likely HRCT findings?
questions.solution:
• Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is a part of a spectrum of diseases caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • Hypersensitive individuals for eg Asthmatic patients can present with ABPA and the key radiological features are Central airway mucoidimpaction leading to central bronchiectasis
  • Halo sign and Air crescent sign are seen in Angioinvasive Aspergillosis seen on Chest X ray
  • Finger in Glove Opacities are seen In Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis- seen on chest X ray is a Sign of mucous plugging seen with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to OPD with symptoms of cough, dyspnea, and lymphadenopathy. Physical exam shows cervical adenopathy and hepatomegaly. Her chest radiograph is shown below. What is the next step to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Sarcoidosis is a systemic illness of unknown etiology with symptoms including cough and dyspnea.
  • Hilar and peripheral lymphadenopathy is common, and 20 to 30% of patients have hepatomegaly.
  • The chest x-ray shows symmetrical hilar lymphadenopathy.
  • The diagnostic method of choice is transbronchial biopsy, which will show a mononuclear cell granulomatous inflammatory process.
  • ACE levels are elevated in two thirds of patients, but false-positive values are common in other granulomatous disease processes.

questions.text: After a right inguinal hernia repair, a man develops erythema over the incision. A wound infection is diagnosed and the patient is discharged home while on 10 days of ciprofloxacin. Three weeks later he returns with complaints of persistent watery diarrhea with a low-grade fever. His temperature is 101°F, his heart rate is 80 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 125/65 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: No treatment, because the cause is probably viral

questions.solution:
• Following a course of antibiotics, one should always be suspicious of the diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis in a patient with the history given.
  • Although this process could be viral, appropriate diagnostic measures should be taken to rule out pseudomembranous colitis.
  • It is generally appropriate to try to confirm the presence of Clostridium difficile cytotoxin in stool specimens, although identifying plaque-like pseudomembranous lesions by colonoscopy would be highly suggestive of such a diagnosis; but this is not routine.
  • Treatment is with oral or intravenous (IV) metronidazole, or nonabsorbable oral vancomycin, although metronidazole is the preferred treatment given the cost considerations and the potential risk of developing vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus strains.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Paralysis of the Recurrent laryngeal nerve ?

choices.text: More Common on the left side
Cord will be in the lateral position on deep inspiration
Speech therapy is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
UNILATERAL RECURRENT LARYNGEAL NERVE PALSY

  • More common on left side than right side because of the longer and more convoluted course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve (Right side is involved only in 3­ to 30% cases).
  • Most unilateral vocal cord paralysis are secondary to surgery.
  • Unilateral injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve leads to ipsilateral paralysis of all intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid (which is an adductor of vocal cord).
  • Vocal cord thus assumes median or paramedian position which does not move laterally on deep inspiration.

Clinical Features:

  • Asymptomatic in 1/3rd cases.
  • In rest of the patients there may be some voice problem i.e. dysphonia—the voice is hoarse and becomes weak with use. This gradually improves with time due to compensation by healthy cord which crosses midline to meet the paralysed one.
  • Generally no speech therapy is required.

questions.text: Which nerve is most at risk in the injury in the given image?
questions.solution:
• The radial nerve runs in a groove on the posterior aspect of the humerus as it courses into the forearm compartment and is therefore at high risk of injury.
  • If the nerve injury is apparent before any manipulation has been done, the fracture should be reduced; the nerve injury should be observed since the nerve function will likely improve with time.
  • If the nerve injury is only present after reduction, immediate surgical exploration is warranted because the nerve might be trapped in the fracture site.
  • At this level of the arm, the ulnar and median nerves are well protected by muscle.
  • The posterior interosseous nerve is a distal branch of the radial nerve and may be injured in fractures near the radial head, but it is in no danger from injuries at the level seen in this radiograph.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with difficulty in breathing and low-grade fever. Upon further questioning, he has had weight loss for the past 6 months and also has poor excursion on the right side of the chest with decreased fremitus, flatness to percussion, and decreased breath sounds all on the right side. The trachea seems to be deviated to the left. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis in this patient is suggested by the physical exam findings.
  • The findings of poor excursion, flatness of percussion, and decreased fremitus on the right side are all consistent with a right-sided pleural effusion.
  • A large right sided effusion may shift the trachea to the left. Histoplasmosis would be one possible cause of such an effusion.
  • A pneumothorax should result in hyperresonance of the affected side.
  • Atelectasis on the right side would shift the trachea to the right.
  • A consolidated pneumonia would characteristically result in increased fremitus, flatness to percussion, and bronchial breath sounds, and would not cause tracheal deviation.

questions.text: A man complains of regurgitation of saliva and of ingested but undigested food. An esophagram reveals a “bird’s beak” deformity. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Chest pain is common in the advanced stages of this disease
More patients are improved by forceful dilation than by surgical intervention
Manometry can be expected to show high resting pressures of the lower esophageal sphincter
Surgical treatment primarily consists of resection of the distal esophagus with reanastomosis to the stomach above the diaphragm

questions.solution:
• Patients with achalasia typically present with distal esophageal obstruction, which leads to regurgitation of saliva and undigested food.
  • The characteristic appearance of the esophagram is the tapered “bird’s beak” deformity at the level of the esophagogastric junction.

  • Chest pain may be seen in the early stages of the disease.
  • Manometry yields high resting pressures of the lower esophageal sphincter, which fails to relax or only partially relaxes.
  • The absence of peristaltic deglutitory contractions in the body of the esophagus is also noted during manometry.
  • Although both surgical intervention and forceful dila- tion have been used to treat this disease, surgery results in improvement in over 90% of patients, compared with only 70% of patients treated by forceful dilation.
  • Surgical treatment is an esophagomyotomy.
  • Patients with achalasia have seven times the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma as compared with the general population.
  • This dreaded complication can occur even after successful treatment for the disease.

questions.text: Dieulafoy’s lesion of the stomach is characterized by

choices.text: A large mucosal defect with underlying, friable vascular plexus
Massive bleeding that requires subtotal gastrectomy

questions.solution:
• Dieulafoy’s lesion has been identified more frequently recently as a source of gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • It is characteristically located within 6 cm distal to the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Dieulafoy’s lesion typically consists of an abnormally large submucosal artery that protrudes through a small, solitary mucosal defect.
  • The lesions may bleed spontaneously and massively for unclear reasons, in which case they require emergency intervention.
  • Upper endoscopy is usually successful in localizing the lesion, and permanent hemostasis can be obtained endoscopically in most cases with injection sclerotherapy, electrocoagulation, or heater probe.
  • If surgery is required, a gastrotomy and simple ligation or wedge resection of the lesion may be adequate.
  • No large series have yet established the optimal surgical treatment for Dieulafoy’s lesion; however, acid-reducing procedures have not been successful in preventing further bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following maternal serum markers is not included in quadruple test for screening in 2nd trimester ?
questions.solution:
Quadruple test :

  • It is done in 2nd trimester for antenatal screening
  • It is usually done between 15-22 weeks
  • It includes :
    • AFP
    • HCG
    • UnconjugatedEstriol
    • Inhibin A

questions.text: A 30 year old obese diabetic mother, delivered a baby by normal vaginal delivery. The newborn will be at risk of developing all except ?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is not a risk factor in infant of diabetic mother

Infants of diabetic mothers are at high risk of developing

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia.
  • Polycythemia :Erythropoiesis stimulated by Hypoxia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
    • After delivery the supply of glucose from mother to fetus stops , but there are still high levels of insulin in baby which causes hypoglycemia.
    • Hypocalcemia is caused by lower parathyroid hormone levels after birth in infants of diabetic mothers . ionized calcium concentrations in utero suppresses the fetal parathyroid glands.

questions.text: A 70 year old man is found to have an asymptomatic carotid bruit. The best initial diagnostic examination would be:
questions.solution:
• Doppler ultrasonography (duplex) has become the best initial test for screening patients with carotid disease.
  • Carotid arteriography remains the “gold standard” when quantifying the degree of carotid stenosis, but it is usually performed after noninvasive testing sug- gests significant stenosis.
  • Spiral CT angiography is a new noninvasive modality that has been used to evaluate many segments of the vascular tree, but as yet its accuracy does not approach that of standard arteriography and it would certainly not be used in the initial evaluation of a patient with an asymptomatic bruit. Magnetic resonance arteriography (MRA) is also a relatively new modality that has enjoyed moderate success in the investiga- tion of carotid disease. Although not quite as accurate as standard arteriog- raphy, it has been used in conjunction with the duplex as a complementary study. Once again, because of its cost, MRA would not be used as the pri- mary screening modality. Transcranial Doppler studies are used to assess the intracranial vasculature.

questions.text: 9 years old boy living in a slum was brought to the OPD by a NGO. He is very thin and underweight for his age. He was diagnosed with marasmus. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition ?
questions.solution:
In marasmus, the patient have Voracious appetite. Poor diet is a feature of kwashiorkor

MARASMUS

  • Marasmus is characterized by severe form of wasting.
  • There is marked wasting of fat and muscle because they are consumed to make energy.
  • The patient have Voracious appetite
  • The patient has <60% of the expected weigth for age.
  • The child appears very thin (skin and bones) and has no fat.
  • There is no edema in marasmus.
  • There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks and thighs.
  • Baggy pants appearance refers to loose skin of the buttocks hanging down.
  • Inspite of their condition these patients are alert and active.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding wound healing and persistent local tissue hypoxia?

choices.text: Fibroblasts are stimulated by low oxygen tension
High lactate levels inhibit macrophage production of angiogenesis factor
Low oxygen tension is the most common cause of poor wound healing
Collagen synthesis is stimulated by hypoxia

questions.solution:
• Oxygen deficiency of the tissues is the most common cause of poor wound healing.
  • Proper tissue oxygenation requires sufficient inspired PO2, transfer of oxygen to hemoglobin, ample hemoglobin for transport, and adequate vascularity of the tissues.
  • Most healing problems associated with diabetes mellitus, irradiation, small vessel atherosclerosis, and chronic infection are a result of a faulty oxygen delivery system.
  • Transiently low wound tissue oxygen levels stimulate cell migration, growth factor release, and collagenase production.
  • Similarly, high lactate levels stimulate the macrophage to produce angiogenesis factors.
  • Fibroblasts are oxygen sensitive and are inhibited by low tissue oxygen tension.
  • Collagen synthesis is also inhibited by low tissue oxygen.

questions.text: An antiglaucoma drug responsible for the adverse effect shown here is:
questions.solution:
Side effects of Prostaglandin Analogues(Latanoprost, Travoprost, Bimatoprost, Tafluprost)

  • Ocular
    • Conjunctival hyperemia
    • Eyelash lengthening
    • Peri-ocular skin hyperpigmentation - may be reversible
    • Irreversible iris hyperpigmentation - due to increase in number of pigment granules in the superficial stroma of the iris (not the pigment cells) - more common in patients with light coloured iris, hence can produce heterochromiairidis
    • Peri-ocular atrophy
    • Cystoid macular edema especially when used in post-operative patients - hence avoided in patients with postoperative glaucoma/IOP spikes
    • Anterior uveitis - hence avoided in patients with inflammatory glaucoma
    • Promotion of herpetic keratitis
  • Systemic
    • Headache, precipitation of migraine
    • Malaise, Myalgia, Skin Rash, mild upper respiratory tract symptoms

questions.text: A 5 months old infant was brought the OPD by her mother with a complaint of bluish discolouration of lips and skin since 2 months of age. It worsens while the baby is crying or suckling. On aauscultation you heard ejection systolic murmur in pulmonary area. Chest X-ray revealed Boot shaped heart. Which of the following is not a key component of this disease ?
questions.solution:
The above given case is of Tetralogy Of Fallot. Large ASD is not a component of TOF.

Tetralogy Of Fallot (TOF)

  • It is the most common congenital heart disease in children.
  • It has 4 components :
    • Large, Unrestricted VSD
    • Pulmonary Stenosis
    • Overriding of Aorta
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy

questions.text: A 17 year old presents to the Emergency Department with his distraught parents. The adolescent is brought with his neck bent to one side with eyes rolled upwards and his tongue is hanging fully out of his mouth. The symptoms regressed after he was given a dose of IV Diphenhydramine. After this intervention, the boy is able to speak and he admits to having taken a few pills at a friend’s house. Which of the following drugs most likely must have caused the above scenario?
questions.solution:
• The boy in the above mentioned clinical vignette experienced an acute dystonic reaction, an adverse effect of neuroleptic medications, secondary to blockage of dopamine receptors in the nigro-striatum system.
  • Dystonic reactions are sustained spasmodic contractions of the muscles of the neck, trunk, tongue, face and the extraocular muscles
  • They can be quite painful and frightening
  • They usually occur within hours to three days after the beginning of the treatment and are more frequent in males and young people
  • They are also usually associated with high potency neuroleptics
  • Occasionally, dystonic reactions are seen in young people who have ingested a neuroleptic medication, mistaking it for a drug of abuse.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy with congenital sensorineural hearing loss and various patches of depigmented lesions all over his body arrives at the OPD with white forelock. On further examination you notice Heterochromia iridis. What is the child suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Waardenburg syndrome is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by a white forelock like piebaldism, cutaneous depigmentation and heterochromia iridis. Sometimes sensorineural deafness is also associated with it

Piebaldism

  • Rare AD disorder of melanocyte development characterized by congenital white forelock and multiple symmetrical hypopigmented or depigmented macules.
  • Etiology: Absence of melanocytes in affected skin and hair follicles as a result of mutations of the KIT proto-oncogene.
  • Symmetric involvement of central forehead, ventral trunk, and mid regions of upper and lower extremities.

Idiopathic Guttate Hypomelanosis (IGH) is a benign and asymptomatic skin manifestation characterized as diffuse small hypopigmented macules, or white spots with angulated margins.

questions.text: Maximun numbers of oogonia are seen in ovaries during :
questions.solution:
• Maximum number of oogonia are seen during 5th month of intrauterine life ( approximately 7 million)
  • At birth there are approximately 2 million and during the start of puberty there are only around 4 lakh.
  • After birth it keeps on decreasing as the females ages, therefore the least are seen after menopause.

questions.text: An elderly male is involved in a motor vehicle accident, where he was traveling at 90 km/hr. His blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg, with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute. After thorough examination his only injuries include a nondisplaced right femur fracture with intact peripheral pulses and some minor abrasions. Which of the following would be appropriate to confirm the absence of a cervical spine injury in this patient?

choices.text: A normal lateral neck film with no cervical tenderness or pain during examination
A normal anterior posterior film with no cervical tenderness or pain during examination
Physical examination alone with no cervical tenderness or pain during examination
Lateral, anterior-posterior, and odontoid views with no cervical tenderness or pain during examination

questions.solution:
• To adequately confirm the absence of a cervical spine injury in a patient at a potential risk for such injury (i.e., high-speed motor vehicle accident) radiographs must be performed.
  • To rely on the physical examination alone, the patient must be alert and oriented and have no distracting injuries (e.g., femur fracture) or be under the influence of drugs.
  • Radiographs needed to evaluate the cervical spine are a lateral, anterior-posterior, and open mouth odontoid views.
  • It is important to visualize all seven cervical vertebrae.
  • If a physical examination is reliable and negative for tenderness or pain with full range of motion, no further evaluation needs to be performed.
  • Even with a normal computed tomography (CT) scan, however, the presence of pain during range of motion testing should prompt an evaluation for a potential ligamentous injury.

questions.text: Most common cause of frequent change in presbyopic glasses among the following are:
questions.solution:
Glaucoma can cause frequent change of presbyopic glasses.

Symptoms of primary open angle glaucoma

  • Asymptomatic most commonly.
  • Headache
  • Frequent change of glasses
  • Delayed dark adaptation
  • Loss of field of vision in advanced cases

questions.text: A woman presents to the ER complaining of redness and pain in her right foot up to the level of the midcalf. She reports that her right leg has been swollen for at least 15 years, but her left leg has been normal. On physical examination she has a temperature of 102.2°F. The left leg is normal. The right leg is not tender, but it is swollen from the inguinal ligament down and there is an obvious cellulitis of the right foot. The patient’s underlying condition is:
questions.solution:
• This patient is at high risk for developing cellulitis of her right foot because her underlying problem is unilateral primary lymphedema.
  • Hypoplasia of the lymphatic system of the lower extremity accounts for greater than 90% of patients with primary lymphedema.
  • The inadequacy of the lymphatic system accounts for the repeated episodes of cellulitis that these patients experience.
  • Swelling is not seen with acute arterial insufficiency or with popliteal entrapment syndrome.
  • Deep venous thrombophlebitis will result in tenderness and is generally not a predisposing factor for cellulitis of the foot.

questions.text: A primigravida with 34 weeks of gestation came to emergency with complaints of headache and blurring of vision since last 3-4 hours. On examination : BP is 160/110 mmHg, urine protein is 2+ , FHR is normal. What would you do next ?
questions.solution:
• The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of impending eclampsia.
  • The next step would be to prevent seizures by MgSO4.
  • After the prevention of seizures and controlling hypertension, the absolute management will be termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 13 year old male presents with complaints of gradual deterioration of vision. Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed a solid mass lesion involving the hypothalamus and the optic chiasm. The visual field defect in this case with optic chiasma compression by the mass is:
questions.solution:
Saggital chiasma lesion

  • Bitemporalhemianopia
  • Partial descending optic atrophy

Causes

  • Suprasellar aneurysm
  • Tumors of pitutory gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic male is being treated for tuberculosis, but he has not been compliant with his medications. He complains of increasing weakness and fatigue.On examination, He appears to have lost weight, and his blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. There is increased pigmentation over the elbows.In the advanced stage of this disease, the most likely electrolyte abnormalities will be

choices.text: Low serum Na+ and high serum K+

questions.solution:
• This patient’s symptoms of weakness, fatigue, and weight loss in combination with signs of hypotension and extensor hyperpigmentation are all consistent with Addison’s disease (adrenal insufficiency).
  • Tuberculosis can involve the adrenal glands and result in adrenal insufficiency.
  • Hyponatremia is due to loss of sodium in the urine (aldosterone deficiency) and movement of sodium intracellularly.
  • Extravascular sodium loss causes hypotension.
  • Hyperkalemia is due to aldosterone deficiency, impaired glomerular filtration, and acidosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has pain in her fingers from exposure to cold, pain in her knees, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Which is the most definitive test to make a profound diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of Raynaud’s phenomenon, arthralgia, and dysphagia point toward the diagnosis of scleroderma.
  • Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis is characterized by a systemic vasculopathy of small and medium-sized vessels, excessive collagen deposition in tissues, and an abnormal immune system.
  • It is an uncommon multisystem disease affecting women more than men.
  • There are two variants of scleroderma—a benign type called the CREST syndrome and a more severe diffuse disease.
  • Antinucleolar antibodies occur in only 20 to 30% of patients with the disease, but a positive test is highly specific.
  • Rheumatoid factor is nonspecific and present in 20% of patients with scleroderma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has recurrent fainting spells induced by fasting. Her serum insulin levels during these episodes are markedly elevated. Correct statements regarding this patient’s condition include which of the following?

choices.text: The underlying lesion is probably an α-cell tumor of the pancreas
The underlying lesion is usually multifocal
She should be screened for a co-existent pheochromocytoma
Serum calcium levels may be elevated

questions.solution:
• Insulin- secreting β-cell tumors of the pancreas produce paroxysmal nervous system manifestations that may be a consequence of hypoglycemia, although the blood glucose level may bear little relation to the severity of the symptoms, even in the same patient from episode to episode.
  • Most insulinomas are single discrete tumors.
  • Patients with insulinoma in the setting of the MEN 1 syndrome (synchronous islet cell tumors of the pancreas, pituitary hyperplasia or adenomas, and parathyroid chief cell hyperplasia), however, are more likely to have multiple tumors throughout the pancreas.
  • If a careful examination of the pancreas reveals one or more specific adenomas, these can be locally excised.
  • Excision of these tumors may be difficult in MEN 1, when the tumors are small and multiple (10–15% of cases).
  • The finding of an elevated serum calcium level would raise the suspicion of MEN 1 and parathyroid hyperplasia.
  • Insulinomas are not associated with MEN 2, which comprises coexistent medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid hyperplasia, and pheochromocytoma.
  • About one in seven of these tumors is malignant.
  • Streptozotocin, a potent antibiotic that selectively destroys islet cells, can be useful in controlling symptoms from unresectable malignant tumors of the islet cells but probably has little to offer in the definitive management of the typical benign islet cell insulinoma.

questions.text: Juvenile Angiofibroma is most commonly supplied by ?
questions.solution:
Juvenile angiofibroma (JA) is a unique tumorpresenting almost exclusively in adolescent males.

The tumorusually arises from the lateral wall of the posterior nasal cavity close to the sphenopalatine

foramen and

the pterygoid base.

It is a vascular tumor and most commonly supplied by sphenopalatine artery

Biopsy is contraindicated since it might precipitate bleeding.

Due to this location nasal obstruction and nasal bleeding may be symptoms presented by the adolescents. Although the tumor is histopathologically classified as a benign lesion, bony erosions of the pterygoid, the clivus and the sphenoid sinus floor are common hallmarks of JAs.

Holman miller sign- Anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary wall

JNAF is best treated by Surgical excision.

  • It is locally invasive invading cheek, orbit, brain, nose
  • Tumor grows into the nasal cavity, nasopharynx and into pterygopalatine fossa, running behind the posterior wall of maxillary sinus which is pushed forward as tumor grows.
  • Laterally it extends into pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.

Most common age group- Adolescents males(Androgen dependent tumor)

  • Patients with advanced and/recurrent JNA thought not to be amenable to complete resection with acceptable morbidity are ones treated with Radiotherapy.

questions.text: During cardiac transplantation, a recipient requires multiple blood transfusions from blood loss during surgery. During the operation, the patient develops sudden hypotension, bleeding from intravenous sites and wound edges, along with severe tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
• Blood transfusion reaction—a type II cytotoxic hypersensitivity—commonly is associated with hypotension, tachycardia, and diffuse bleeding in an anesthetized patient.
  • This reaction occurs when preformed antibodies to transfused red blood cell antigens are present in the recipient, leading to complement mediated lysis.
  • Type I reactions are mediated by immunoglobulin IgE to allergen, leading to mast cell or basophil degranulation.
  • Previous aspirin or warfarin therapy would likely be associated with persistent bleeding throughout the operation and would not lead to sudden hypotension.
  • Type IV sensitivity occurs 48–72 hours after exposure to antigen and is associated with sensitized helper T cells.

questions.text: A couple presented to the psychiatric OPD where the husband says he witnessed an episode of sleepwalking by his wife which she has no memory of. He also says she relocates belongings from their room to the hall or she will start tidying up the room. The following are parasomnia EXCEPT
questions.solution:
List of common Parasomnia (Parasomnia are sleep disorders appearing during the sleep)

  • Somniloquy
  • Somnambulism
  • Nocturnal enuresis
  • Sleep walking
  • Sleep terrors
  • Night mares

List of common Dyssomnia (Dyssomnia are sleep disorders affecting the quantity and quality of sleep)

  • Insomnia
  • Hypersomnia
  • Jet lag syndrome
  • Sleep – wake disorders
  • Narcolepsy

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of intense pain and tenderness over the right ankle. There is no history of trauma. The patient has hypertension and is taking a mild diuretic for the same. On examination, his ankle is swollen and tender.What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain uric acid level and perform arthrocentesis
Obtain uric acid level and perform arthrocentesis
Obtain ankle x-ray to rule out fracture

questions.solution:
• The sudden onset and severity of this monoarticular arthritis suggests acute gouty arthritis, especially in a patient on diuretic therapy.
  • However, an arthrocentesis is indicated in the first episode to document gout by demonstrating needle shaped, negatively birefringent crystals and to rule out other diagnoses such as infection.
  • For most patients with acute gout, NSAIDs are the treatment of choice.
  • Colchicine is also effective, but causes nausea and diarrhea. Antibiotics should not be started for infectious arthritis before an arthrocentesis is performed.

questions.text: A 19 year old girl presents with an anterior neck mass. Her thyroid scan, shown below, is most consistent with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
• The thyroid gland originates embryologically from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue.
  • Normally, the thyroglossal duct becomes obliterated and resorbed, but portions may remain patent and become filled with serous fluid, which produces a midline cervical mass.
  • Observe that in the scan of the patient described in the question, the mass is central and appears not to be part of the gland itself.

questions.text: A 22 year old anxious woman who is on birth control pills presents to the emergency room with shortness of breath. The absence of which of the following would make the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism unlikely?
questions.solution:
• While all of these signs and symptoms can occur in acute pulmonary embolism, tachypnea is by far the most common
  • Tachypnea occurs in more than 90% of patients with pulmonary embolism.
  • Pleuritic chest pain occurs in about half of patients and is less common in the elderly and those with underlying heart disease.
  • Hemoptysis and wheezing occur in less than half of patients.
  • A right-sided S3 is associated with large emboli that result in acute pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 37 year old unemployed man comes to the OPD with itchiness, soreness, or a burning sensation in and around the affected areas of skin. The Extensor aspect of his skin also has silvery- whitish scales which upon scratching bleeds. Histopathology of the lesion is least likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Clubbing of rete ridges at the base

questions.solution:
The above image shows Pink-red, silvery scales, sharply demarcated edges characteristic of psoriasis. Munro Microabscess is seen in psoriasis whereas Pautrier’s Microabscess is seen in Mycosis fungoides

Histopathology of PSORIASIS:

Early changes

  • Vasodilatation, papillary oedema and leukocyte infiltrates appear to precede epidermal changes in early developing lesions.
  • Compact hyperkeratosis, disappearance of the granular layer and slight epidermal hyperplasia follow. Mitotic figures in keratinocytes,and leukocytic infiltration in spongiotic foci, are seen in the lower half of the epidermis. Scattered mounds of parakeratosis, set in a still predominantly orthokeratotic stratum corneum, appear, with or without neutrophils.
  • In the Malpighian layer,neutrophils may accumulate to form the characteristic spongiform pustules of Kogoj.
  • Epidermal hyperplasia with rete ridges of even length and prominently dilated, tortuous papillary capillaries associated with mixed mononuclear and neutrophil infiltrates are seen.

Changes in fully developed plaques:

  • There is parakeratosis associated with focal orthokeratosis and Munro microabscess formation, near absence of the granular layer, spongiform pustules in the Malpighian layer, hyperplasia with elongation of rete ridges and suprapapillary epidermal thinning.
  • The rete ridges are often clubbed, branched or fused at their bases, with mononuclear leukocyte infiltrates in the lower half of the epidermis.
  • Dilated, tortuous papillary blood vessels almost touch the undersurface of the thinning suprapapillary epidermis and are surrounded by a mixed mononuclear and neutrophilic infiltrate, as well as extravasated erythrocytes

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hypospadias is correct?

choices.text: It is often associated with chordee
The most common location is penoscrotal
It is a rare fusion defect of the posterior male urethra
It occurs sporadically, without evidence of familial inheritance

questions.solution:
• Hypospadias is a common congenital anomaly of the penis resulting from incomplete development of the anterior urethra.
  • It occurs in about 1 in 300 live births and is believed to have a multifactorial genetic mode of inheritance.
  • Of those with hypospadias, about 7% have a father with the disorder, 14% a brother, and 20% a second family member.
  • Hypospadias occurs in the corona in about 75% of cases, where it is often accompanied by chordee.
  • Undescended testes occur in about 10% of cases of hypospadias, as do inguinal hernias.
  • Hypospadias in the scrotal area is associated with bilateral undescended testes and infertility and must be differentiated from pseudohermaphroditism and adrenogenital syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following can be associated with Keratoconus, EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Senile cataract is not an association with keratoconus

Important Associations of Keratoconus :

  • Leber congenital amaurosis
  • Vernal kerato conjunctivitis
  • Down’s syndrome
  • Atopy
  • Floppy eyelid syndrome
  • Ehler Danlos
  • Achondroplasia
  • Alagille syndrome
  • Apert syndrome
